item.title: An Introduction to CSIDH
item.description:
This is meant to be an expository post to the Commutative Supersingular Isogeny Diffie-Hellman (CSIDH) key exchange protocol. As is often the case, if you’re interested in the full details of CSIDH, there is no better resource than the original paper Castryck et al. (2018).

Mathematical Background

I’ll begin this section by introducing some of the basic mathematical concepts needed. My goal is to make this section accessible to someone who has minimal training in mathematics.

Groups

We’ll be working a lot with algebraic sets known as groups. Formally, a group is a non-empty set along with a binary operation that satisfies the following:

  1. Identity: There exists a unique element in such that for any in
  2. Associativity: Let be elements of Then
  3. Inverses: For any in , there exists a unique element such that We denote this element

Loosely speaking, a group is a set of objects which we can “add” together to get other objects in the group. There exists an element known as the identity, and it is the “do-nothing” element (i.e. if we “add” it to something else, nothing happens). We can obtain by “subtracting” any object from itself.
